page.title:
Sloan Digital Sky Survey
Sloan Digital Sky Survey
page.enlisting:
• Digital map in 5 spectral bands covering ¼ of the sky. • Will obtain 40 TB of raw pixel data. • Photometric catalog with more than 200 million objects. • Spectra of 1 million objects. • Data Release One – DR1: 6 TB of images, 200 k spectra.

page.title:
The SkyServer Database
The SkyServer Database
page.footer:
María Nieto-Santisteban – AISRP 2003 / Pittsburgh
María Nieto-Santisteban – AISRP 2003 / Pittsburgh M a r í a
N i e t o - S a n t i s t e b a n
– A I S R P
2 0 0 3
/
P i t t s b u r g h
page.enlisting:
• Processed data is stored into a relational database, SkyServer. • Allows fast exploration and analysis of the data (Data Mining). • DR1 data base (Best + Target): ~ 1TB and 6TB for final • Heavily indexed to speed up access. • Short queries can run interactively. • Long queries (> 1 hour) require a custom Batch Query System. • DBMS, Microsoft SQL Server 2000. • Processed data is stored into a relational database, SkyServer. • Allows fast exploration and analysis of the data (Data Mining). • DR1 data base (Best + Target): ~ 1TB and 6TB for final

page.enlisting:
• Partitioning works well if tables in the database are • Partitioning is most effective if the tables in the database can be partitioned symmetrically. (Not exactly our case) • Related data should be placed on the same member server so most SQL statements routed to a member will require minimum data from other servers. • Data should be partitioned uniformly across the member • Partitioning works well if tables in the database are

page.enlisting:
• Two-Step Process 1. Distribute data homogenously among servers. 2. • Two-Step Process
• Two-Step Process • T w o - S t e p
P r o c e s s
1. Distribute data homogenously among servers. 2. 1. Distribute data homogenously among servers.
1. Distribute data homogenously among servers.
2.
2.

- Each server has roughly the same amount of objects. - Objects inside servers are spatially related. - Balances the workload among servers. - Queries redirected to the server holding the data. (Re)Define zones inside each server dynamically. - Zones are defined according to some search radius to solve specific problems: - Finding Galaxy Cluster, - Gravitational Lenses, etc. - Facilitates cross-match queries from other NVO data - Each server has roughly the same amount of objects. - Objects inside servers are spatially related. - Balances the workload among servers. - Queries redirected to the server holding the data. (Re)Define zones inside each server dynamically. - Zones are defined according to some search radius

page.title:
Mapping the Sphere into Zones
Mapping the Sphere into Zones
page.footer:
María Nieto-Santisteban – AISRP 2003 / Pittsburgh
María Nieto-Santisteban – AISRP 2003 / Pittsburgh M a r í a
N i e t o - S a n t i s t e b a n
– A I S R P
2 0 0 3
/
P i t t s b u r g h
page.enlisting:
• Each Zone is a declination stripe of height h. • In principle, h can be any number. In practice, 30 arcsec. (DR1 => 8000 ZONES) • South-pole zone = Zone 0. • Each object belongs to one Zone: • Each server holds N “contiguous” Zones. • N is determined by the number of objects that each Zone contains and the number of servers in the cluster. – Not all servers contain the same number of zones. – Not all servers cover the same declination range. • Straightforward mapping between queries and servers. • Each Zone is a declination stripe of height h. • In principle, h can be any number. In practice, 30 arcsec.
